title: R42389
content: Child support is a cash payment that noncustodial parents must pay for their children's financial support. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program, established in 1975, helps secure financial support for children from noncustodial parents and promotes self-sufficiency for families. The program is based on the idea that both parents are responsible for their children's financial well-being. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program has evolved into a "family-first" service delivery program that aims to enhance the well-being of families by ensuring child support payments. States use various methods, including the threat of jail, to collect child support. Failure to pay child support is considered a violation of a court order, which can be treated as contempt of court, a civil offense, or a criminal offense. In the CSE program, caseworkers have discretion in managing cases, including issuing warrants for noncompliant noncustodial parents. Some parents claim they were arrested after appearing in court for child support. Jail threat is seen as a temporary fix by judges, but effective in some cases. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program operates in all 50 states and provides various services for children, including parent location, paternity establishment, and collection of child support payments. Incarceration of noncustodial parents for nonpayment of child support lacks national data on its frequency and magnitude. The Child Support Enforcement (CSE) program utilizes various methods to obtain child support obligations, including income withholding, intercept of tax refunds, liens against property, and suspension of licenses. Federal law mandates states to enact the Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) to enforce interstate child support cases effectively. The Uniform Interstate Family Support Act (UIFSA) is implemented to enforce interstate child support cases effectively. Federal law allows for international enforcement of child support and imposes federal criminal penalties in certain cases. Income withholding is the most effective enforcement tool, with 67% of child support payments collected through this method in FY2010. Other enforcement methods include intercepting tax refunds, withholding unemployment benefits, and utilizing civil or criminal contempt-of-court procedures. The federal Office of Child Support Enforcement (OCSE) collects child support payments through various methods, including income tax refund offset, state income tax refund offset, and other sources. Rough estimates suggest that a small percentage of child support collections are associated with the threat of incarceration. States have historically addressed nonpayment of child support, with enforcement measures dating back to 1910. In 1910, the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws approved the Uniform Desertion and Non-Support Act to address the problem of nonpayment of child support. This act imposed criminal penalties on fathers who failed to support their children. However, as the U.S. population became more mobile, welfare agencies had to support destitute families due to inefficient extradition processes. In 1950, the Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act (URESA) was published to improve and extend the enforcement of support duties across states through criminal and civil enforcement methods. Criminal and civil enforcement methods for child support obligations have been debated. While jail was traditionally used, it was seen as counterproductive as it burdened the state with supporting the family. Despite concerns, criminal enforcement was kept in the Act due to its traditional nature and the belief that civil enforcement may not cover all cases. Penalties for nonpayment of child support, including imprisonment, have gained support in recent years. State and federal laws penalize noncustodial parents for not paying child support, categorizing them as "can't pay" or "won't pay" parents. Aggressive enforcement tools target "won't pay" parents who refuse to meet their obligations despite having the means to do so, leading to the use of criminal statutes and contempt of court orders. This distinction can be complex, with some low-income parents claiming they are wrongly labeled as "won't pay" parents. In some countries, noncustodial parents can be sent to jail for not paying child support. However, not all countries use imprisonment as a penalty for nonpayment. For example, Australia and Finland do not imprison individuals for failing to pay child support. Denmark, although it specifies criminal prosecution and imprisonment, has never actually prosecuted or incarcerated anyone for nonpayment of child support. Low-income noncustodial parents can be incarcerated for nonpayment of child support or contempt of court charges related to nonpayment. Contempt of court occurs when a court order is not followed, and state courts can punish individuals for violating judgments. Contempt can be civil or criminal, depending on the purpose of the penalty imposed. Civil contempt of court occurs when an individual willfully disobeys a court order or rule, leading to potential fines or jail time as a means to coerce compliance rather than punish. This is commonly seen in cases involving child support enforcement, where noncustodial parents may face jail time until they fulfill their financial obligations. Compliance with court requirements resolves the contempt charge. In civil contempt of court cases, individuals must comply with court requirements to no longer be in contempt, such as paying child support arrearages or participating in work/training programs. On the other hand, criminal contempt occurs when someone disrupts court proceedings, leading to fines, jail time, or both. The purpose of criminal contempt charges is to punish and deter future acts of contempt, separate from the underlying case. Criminal contempt charges are separate from the underlying case and may persist after its resolution. It can be challenging to classify contempt as civil or criminal, leading to potential wrongful incarceration if misclassified. Civil contempt actions are typically against noncustodial parents with poor child support payment histories to encourage compliance. In civil contempt actions, the goal is to enforce compliance with child support orders by noncustodial parents through fines or incarceration if necessary. Sanctions include coercive fines to the court, compensatory fines to the custodial parent, or imprisonment, but only if it benefits the children and allows the noncustodial parent to avoid punishment by meeting specific requirements. Rogers case established that punishment cannot be imposed if the parent is unable to comply with the order, and once the delinquent parent fulfills their obligation, they are considered purged of contempt. Unlike criminal defendants, civil defendants do not have the same constitutional protections, such as the right to an attorney. The U.S. Supreme Court is considering whether indigent noncustodial parents should be provided legal representation in such cases. The U.S. Supreme Court in Turner v. Rogers declined to rule that the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause requires legal representation for indigent noncustodial parents facing imprisonment for noncompliance with child support orders. The case involved a South Carolina child support case where the defendant spent a year in jail without legal representation, despite presenting evidence of inability to work. The legislation targeted difficult interstate cases where parents refused to pay, aiming to deter noncompliance with child support obligations. "Project Save Our Children" is a federal initiative aimed at pursuing chronic delinquent parents who owe significant child support, with the goal of increasing collections through identification, investigation, and prosecution of offenders.
